awd_titl_txt: EFRI CEE: Macrogenomic engineering via modulation of chromatin nanoenvironment
awd_abstract_narration:
The function of organisms is determined not only by their genes but also by their capacity to express these genes. The adaptive potential of organisms is determined by their capacity to explore their landscape of thousands of genes and create new functional states. Currently no platform allows for the predictable modulation of this many genes simultaneously. The goal of this project is to build the foundations of such a technology, termed macrogenomic engineering. The principles of macrogenomic engineering can be applied to attack the key reason why most currently available anti-cancer treatments fail. In addition to addressing tumor drug resistance this program will impact some of the most significant diseases of the 21st century involving changes in gene expression in Alzheimer's disease and atherosclerosis.

Transcriptional interactions depend on the local physical nanoenvironment, which in turn depends on the three-dimensional structure of the genome. This project will develop physico-chemical methodologies to reversibly manipulate the chromatin nanoenvironment thus affecting transcriptional processes in a predictable manner. This will enable the modulation of the adaptive potential of cells by regulating the degree of freedom within the transcriptome. The first two objectives of the project are to elucidate physico-chemical factors that determine the properties of chromatin packing and the role of the resulting chromatin nanoenvironment in modulating gene networks, intercellular, and temporal transcriptional heterogeneity. The third objective is to apply the principles of macrogenomic engineering to a testbed. The testbed explored in this project is carcinogenesis. Transcriptional diversity is a major reason why tumors eventually develop resistance to most therapies. The project will develop physico-chemical strategies to constrain transcriptional diversity and the adaptive potential of cancer cells in order to prevent the progression of pancreatic and ovarian tumors in animal models and to prevent the emergence of resistance to anti-cancer therapeutics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit and Background of the Project:

DNA, which encodes all genetic information, is stored inside the nucleus, where it is transcribed into mRNA and translated into proteins. This process is known as gene expression and collectively defines a cell’s processes and functionality. Chromatin, the 3-D structure formed by nuclear DNA and associated proteins, plays a central role in regulating gene accessibility for transcription. As a result, alterations in chromatin structure are linked to many human diseases such as cancer. Chromatin is organized across multiple length scales, from DNA at sub-10 nm scales to larger chromatin domains (~100 nm), compartments (~0.5 µm), and chromosome territories within the nucleus (~1-2 µm) scale. All of these length scales influence gene transcription through complex mechanisms that have been difficult to disentangle. This project aims to (1) identify the fundamental biophysical factors that regulate chromatin organization and modulate gene activity and (2) identify pharmacological compounds that influence the physical structure of chromatin and consequently gene expression in cancer cells. Thus, by physically manipulating the chromatin structure we seek to reduce the adaptability of cancer cells, enhance chemotherapy efficacy, and prevent cancer tumor cells from developing resistance to treatments.

Summary of the Project Findings

We have developed two innovative technologies to study chromatin and the genome. First, we developed our chromatin nanoimaging and analysis platform, nano-ChIA, where ChromSTEM “microscopy” visualizes chromatin with unprecedented resolution, capturing details down to 5 nanometers. This was complemented with Partial Wave Spectroscopic (PWS) microscopy, which measures the statistical properties of chromatin conformation with sensitivity to 20 nm chromatin chain size for live cells in a non-invasive manner (other imaging techniques require fixation and/or staining of cells). Second, we developed two computational models to simulate the structure of chromatin and predict gene expression patterns. The self-returning random walk model captures statistical properties of chromatin conformation on scales from 10 nm to 1000 nm. In parallel, our chromatin packing molecular crowding model predicts gene expression by linking chromatin’s nanoscale environment with a system of rate equations that account for transport properties and reaction constants based on the local chromatin volume concentration. Combined with nano-ChIA, we found that chromatin packing, i.e., the spatial and temporal statistical organization of chromatin, can modulate gene expression by orders of magnitude. Through these imaging and modeling approaches, we identified transcriptional divergence, meaning differential gene expression, as a predictor of survival time in lung, colon, and breast cancer patients. This insight led us to propose pharmaceutical compounds that can alter the chromatin structure and their transcriptional (gene expression) patterns, which, when combined with existing cancer therapeutics, significantly enhance their efficacy. Thus, our advancements in chromatin imaging and modeling not only deepen our understanding of chromatin structure and gene expression patterns but also led us to propose new physics-based strategies in cancer therapeutics, which will pave the way to the development of new approaches to cancer therapy and prevention, and interventions for other diseases and conditions rooted in genomic processes.

Broader Impacts

The project provided training for nine postdocs, twelve graduate students, twenty-nine undergraduate students, and four high school students. The students and postdocs were trained in a variety of techniques including biomedical optics, electron microscopy, and molecular dynamics simulations.

A supplementary Research Experience and Mentoring (REM) Program was awarded in year 3. The REM supplement award funded seventeen undergraduate students from traditionally underrepresented groups in STEM (e.g., certain racial and ethnic minorities, women in STEM, first-generation college students, etc.). Students participated in a 6-7 week summer research experience and received mentorship and research training from EFRI mentors based on research interest and background.

The project interactions have exposed the (under) graduate students, postdocs and REM students to new insights and training, which will impact and advance their future scientific research and or commercial careers.

Dissemination and Resource Development

Research staff including the co-PI’s gave talks directed at lay audiences, including high-school students, and the PI taught undergraduate classes on physical optics. Results from this project have contributed to the infrastructure at Northwestern University by means of the development of a new optical nanoimaging platform, which is currently the most advanced chromatin imaging platform in the world, and which is now available to other investigators as a common resource.

The research of this project has directly deepened our understanding of the behavior of chromatin and how it affects gene expression. This new understanding allows us to propose new cancer therapeutic strategies. In the long term, the results of this project will enable the development and dissemination of new approaches to cancer prevention and interventions for other diseases and conditions rooted in genomic processes.
